title: How much does traffic congestion cost Denver each year?
text:
How much does traffic congestion cost Denver each year? Aug 27, 2015, 7:07am MDT Industries & Tags Kathleen Lavine | Denver Business Journal The average Denver driver spends 49 hours a year stopped in traffic. Those traffic backups on I-25 and I-70 each morning and evening? They're expensive. According to a new report, traffic congestion costs the Denver area more than $2 billion each year. Denver commuters spent more than 91 million hours in morning and afternoon rush hour traffic delays last year, according to the report, which is the 18th-most in the country. The new by Texas A&Mâ€™s Transportation Institute indicates that the average Denver driver spends 49 hours a year stopped in traffic, which is the 19th-most of any city of the 470 cities covered in the report. When you figure in the costs of idling by commuters and truckers in traffic jams, the total congestion costs in Denver are more than $2 billion a year. The New York traffic is the worst in the country, with congestion costing that municipal area more than $14 billion per year.
